technicalRecon.subtitle: Azure OpenAI backend, Microsoft Graph APIs, and consumer Copilot architecture

apiArchitecture.title: Azure OpenAI (Developer) + Microsoft Graph Copilot APIs + No Consumer Parental API
apiArchitecture.description: Microsoft Copilot is powered by Azure OpenAI Service (GPT-4o and o-series models), orchestrated through Microsoft Graph and the Microsoft Copilot system. Developers access AI capabilities via the Azure OpenAI REST API — a fully documented, enterprise-grade API. Microsoft Graph provides Copilot extensibility APIs (graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/copilot and /beta/copilot) for building agents and extensions. However, there is NO API for consumer Copilot parental controls — Family Safety configuration is web-dashboard-only. No consumer conversation access, no usage stats API, and no safety event webhooks exist for Phosra integration.

authDetails.label: Azure OpenAI Developer API
authDetails.value: Azure API Key or Entra ID OAuth 2.0
authDetails.description: Resource-scoped Azure API keys. Enterprise users can use Entra ID (formerly Azure AD) managed identities for keyless authentication. Rate limits tiered by Azure subscription level. RBAC permissions via Azure portal.

authDetails.label: Consumer Copilot
authDetails.description: Standard MSA (Microsoft account) web session. OAuth 2.0 SSO with Microsoft, Google, or email/password. The consumer Copilot web interface is protected; no programmatic session access. Limited guest mode available without login.

authDetails.label: Microsoft Graph Copilot APIs
authDetails.description: Enterprise Copilot extensibility uses Microsoft Graph with delegated or application permissions. Scopes: AiInteractionRead, CopilotInteract. Requires admin consent. Rate limits follow Microsoft Graph throttling policies.

authDetails.label: Family Safety Dashboard
authDetails.description: Parent logs in to family.microsoft.com or the Family Safety app. No API, no webhooks, no programmatic access to Family Safety controls. Any Phosra integration would require fragile session automation.

rateLimitNotes: Consumer Copilot free tier: approximately 30 turns per conversation thread; throttled during peak demand. No published daily message cap.
Copilot Pro ($20/month): higher per-thread turn cap, priority compute access during peak times.
Azure OpenAI API: quota by model and subscription tier. GPT-4o: 10,000 TPM (tokens per minute) for S0 tier; scalable to 300,000+ TPM for higher tiers. Contact Azure for enterprise limits.
Microsoft Graph API: 10,000 requests per 10 minutes per app per tenant (standard throttling). Copilot Graph APIs follow Graph rate limit policies.
Bing Search API (developer): 3 calls/second for S1 tier; higher tiers available.
Guest access (no account): stricter per-conversation turn limits than authenticated users; degraded feature access.

tosWarning.title: Microsoft Terms of Service — Automated and Programmatic Access
tosWarning.description: Microsoft's Terms of Service prohibit automated access to the consumer Copilot web interface (copilot.microsoft.com). The Azure OpenAI developer API is designed for programmatic access but does NOT expose consumer parental controls or family features. Automating the Microsoft Family Safety dashboard (family.microsoft.com) would violate Microsoft's ToS. Phosra's browser extension approach (client-side, user-installed parental control) is the most defensible integration path. Network-level DNS blocking of copilot.microsoft.com is fully compliant.

overallRisk.description: Microsoft Copilot presents lower child safety risk than most AI chatbot competitors due to: (1) hard block for under-13 accounts, (2) automatic teen-tier protections for 13-17, (3) explicit policy rejection of romantic/companion AI, and (4) productivity-first product positioning. The main risk gaps are lack of content-level parental alerts and the ease of circumvention via unmanaged devices or new accounts.

detectionVectors.mitigation: User-installed parental control extensions are not blocked by Microsoft. Chrome/Edge extension can monitor copilot.microsoft.com sessions.
Microsoft ToS prohibits automation of family.microsoft.com. Use Family Safety APIs if/when Microsoft publishes them. Avoid Playwright automation of the dashboard.
Blocking copilot.microsoft.com at router/DNS level is fully compliant and transparent to Microsoft.

detectionVectors.vector: Azure OpenAI API use for content moderation
detectionVectors.mitigation: Azure Content Safety API (cognitive.azure.com/contentsafety) is designed for this use case — legitimate, documented, enterprise-grade.
Copilot uses streaming responses over HTTPS. Extension monitoring of streamed text is standard browser capability. Microsoft does not actively detect or block extension-based monitoring.

mitigationsChecklist: Use browser extension for client-side monitoring of copilot.microsoft.com (user-consented, ToS-compatible)
Use Azure Content Safety API (or OpenAI Moderation API) for content classification — legitimate use case
Use DNS/network-level controls for enforcement — block copilot.microsoft.com and related domains
Avoid automating family.microsoft.com — Microsoft ToS prohibits this; use official Family Safety controls instead
Instruct parents to manually configure Microsoft Family Safety for app-level blocking and screen time on enrolled devices
Account for iOS gap — Family Safety does not manage iOS; advise Apple Screen Time setup separately
Block guest access at network level — guest mode bypasses all account-level controls
Monitor Microsoft Graph Copilot API announcements — enterprise parental-style controls may be added
Educate parents on multi-device bypass risk — controls only apply to enrolled Microsoft ecosystem devices

gapOpportunities.title: Zero Parental Safety Alerts
gapOpportunities.gap: Microsoft Copilot sends NO safety alerts to parents — not even for crisis-level content (self-harm, violent ideation). Unlike ChatGPT which has a crisis notification system, Copilot has zero parent notification infrastructure. Parents using Family Safety only see screen time data, not content safety events.
gapOpportunities.solution: Phosra browser extension monitors Copilot conversations in real-time. Azure Content Safety API classifies messages. Immediate push notifications to parent with severity level (critical / high / medium) and content category when concerning content is detected.

gapOpportunities.title: No Copilot-Specific Time Limits
gapOpportunities.gap: While Microsoft Family Safety provides app-level screen time on Windows/Xbox/Android, there are no Copilot-native daily or weekly time limits. iOS devices are excluded from Family Safety entirely. Time limits do not work for browser-based Copilot access on unmanaged devices.
gapOpportunities.solution: Phosra extension tracks active Copilot session time on managed browsers. When daily limit is reached, extension blocks the Copilot interface. DNS-level domain blocking prevents bypass via other browsers or incognito mode.

gapOpportunities.title: No Parent-Configurable Message Limits
gapOpportunities.gap: Copilot's turn limits are technical throttling, not parental safety controls. Parents cannot set custom daily message limits for their child's Copilot usage. The Family Safety screen time budget is the only proxy control.
gapOpportunities.solution: Phosra extension counts messages exchanged per session and per day. When the parent-configured limit is reached, the Copilot input field is blocked and a friendly limit-reached message is displayed.

gapOpportunities.title: Academic Integrity Monitoring
gapOpportunities.gap: Copilot is deeply integrated into Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and OneNote — the primary tools students use for schoolwork. There is no academic integrity detection in consumer Copilot. Assignment-level controls exist in the Microsoft 365 Education version (preview Feb 2026) but not for consumer accounts.
gapOpportunities.solution: Phosra extension detects Copilot usage patterns consistent with homework completion — essay generation requests, test question answering — and alerts parents. For Microsoft 365 Education tenants, Phosra can complement the Assignment-level AI controls with parent-facing reporting.

gapOpportunities.title: Cross-Device Visibility Gap
gapOpportunities.gap: Microsoft Family Safety manages Windows, Xbox, and Android devices but NOT iOS or macOS. The Copilot iOS app and Safari-based access to copilot.microsoft.com are entirely outside Family Safety coverage.
gapOpportunities.solution: Phosra provides cross-platform visibility by combining: (1) browser extension on Windows/macOS, (2) iOS Screen Time API integration where available, and (3) network-level DNS monitoring that is device-agnostic.

integrationGap.apiDescription: Azure Content Safety API (classification) + Extension (monitoring) + DNS (enforcement) + Family Safety manual setup guide

steps.title: Monitor
steps.detail: Browser extension observes messages on copilot.microsoft.com using MutationObserver. Captures visible user and AI message text, counts conversation turns, tracks session duration. Extension works in Edge, Chrome, and Firefox on desktop. Does not require Microsoft account credentials — monitors the page DOM directly after user loads Copilot.

steps.title: Classify
steps.description: Analyze content with Azure Content Safety
steps.detail: Captured conversation text sent to Azure Content Safety API for classification across harm categories: hate, self-harm, sexual, violence (each with severity 0-6). More detailed than OpenAI Moderation API — includes severity scoring not just binary flags. Typical latency: ~150-300ms. Priced per 1,000 text records; enterprise SLA available.

steps.title: Enforce
steps.detail: Time limit reached: extension overlays a friendly block screen on copilot.microsoft.com. DNS/router-level block of copilot.microsoft.com prevents bypass via other browsers or incognito mode. Complements Microsoft Family Safety app-level blocking (Windows/Xbox/Android) with browser-level enforcement for any device.

steps.title: Notify
steps.description: Instant parent alert — fills critical gap
steps.detail: Push notification to parent via Phosra app. Severity level, content category, and context included. Critical finding: Microsoft Copilot has ZERO native parental safety alerts — not even for self-harm content. Phosra fills this gap completely. Screen time summary also delivered (daily Copilot usage, turn count, topics detected).

limitations.title: iOS / macOS not covered by Family Safety
limitations.description: Microsoft Family Safety does not manage iOS or macOS devices. The Copilot iOS app and Safari browser access are outside Family Safety coverage. Parents must set up Apple Screen Time separately. Phosra browser extension does not cover mobile apps.

limitations.title: Guest access bypasses account controls
limitations.description: Copilot allows limited guest access without a Microsoft account. Guest mode bypasses teen-tier protections, age verification, and any account-linked family controls. DNS/network blocking is the only defense against guest access on managed networks.

limitations.title: Copilot embedded in Windows system features
limitations.description: On Windows 11 devices, Copilot may be accessible via the Copilot key, taskbar button, or system-level integration — separate from the Copilot app. These entry points may not be blocked by app-level Family Safety controls targeting only the downloaded Copilot app.

limitations.title: Extension can be disabled by tech-savvy teens
limitations.description: A teen can disable or remove the browser extension. Phosra detects missing extension heartbeat and alerts the parent. DNS/network-level blocking remains active even without the extension.

enforcementFlow.loopLabel: Continuous monitoring while Copilot is active in the browser

methods.name: installExtension
methods.recommendation: Distribute via Chrome Web Store and Microsoft Edge Add-ons store. Auto-configure via Phosra account linking. Targets copilot.microsoft.com domain.

methods.name: trackConversations
methods.recommendation: MutationObserver on Copilot chat container. Capture user and assistant turns separately. Handle Copilot's streaming text rendering. Track turn count per conversation thread.

methods.name: trackSessionTime
methods.recommendation: Active tab timer on copilot.microsoft.com domain. Background service worker persists timer across tab focus changes.

methods.name: classifyContent
methods.recommendation: POST to cognitive.azure.com/contentsafety/text:analyze. Returns severity scores (0-6) for hate, self-harm, sexual, violence. More granular than OpenAI Moderation API. Phosra's Azure subscription keeps costs low.

methods.name: enforceTimeLimits
methods.recommendation: Extension overlays block screen when time limit reached. DNS blocks copilot.microsoft.com to prevent incognito/other browser bypass. Block list: copilot.microsoft.com, www.bing.com/chat (legacy Bing Chat URL).

methods.name: enforceQuietHours
methods.recommendation: Schedule DNS blocking of copilot.microsoft.com during parent-configured quiet hours. Complements but does not depend on Microsoft Family Safety screen time scheduling.

methods.name: setupFamilySafety
methods.recommendation: Phosra provides a step-by-step setup guide directing parents to configure Microsoft Family Safety (app blocking, screen time) on enrolled devices. No API automation needed — guided UX is sufficient and ToS-compliant.

methods.name: blockGuestAccess
methods.recommendation: Block copilot.microsoft.com at network/router level for all devices on the home network. Prevents anonymous guest access that bypasses all account-level controls.

methods.name: detectCrisisContent
methods.recommendation: Monitor for self-harm severity scores >= 3 via Azure Content Safety API. Immediate parent push notification. Critical gap fill: Microsoft Copilot has NO native parental crisis alerts — this is Phosra's highest-value Copilot integration.
